sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The matters done,
I must not stay to bury him.

div.head: Act v.

sp.speaker: 1 lord.
sp.l: Columbo's death doth much afflict the King.

sp.speaker: 2 lo.
sp.l: I thought the Cardinal would have lost his wits
At first, for's nephew, it drowns all the talk
Of the other that were slain.
We are friends.
I do suspect Hernando had some interest
And knew how their wounds came.
His flight confirms it,
For whom the Cardinal has spread his nets.
He is not so weak to trust himself at home
To his enemies gripe.
All strikes not me so much,
As that the Duchess, most oppressed lady,
Should be distracted, and before Columbo
Was slain.
But that the Cardinal should be made
Her guardian, is to me above that wonder.
So it pleased the King, and she, with that small stock
Of reason left her, is so kind, and smooth
Upon him.
She's turned a child again; a madness,
That would ha' made her brain and blood boil high
In which distemper she might ha' wrought something.
Had been to purpose.
The Cardinal is cunning, and howe'er
His brow does smile, he does suspect Hernando
Took fire from her, and waits a time to punish it.
But what a subject of disgrace, and mirth,
Hath poor Celinda made herself by pride,
In her belief Columbo was her servant.
Her head hath stooped much since he died, and she
Almost ridiculous at court.
The Cardinal
Is come into the garden, now —

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Walk off,
It troubles me the Duchess by her loss
Of brain is now beneath my great revenge,
She is not capable to feel my anger,
Which like to unregarded thunder spent
In woods, and lightning aimed at senseless trees,
Must idly fall, and hurt her not, not to
That sense her guilt deserves a fatal stroke,
Without the knowledge for what crime to fright her,
When she takes leave, and make her tug with death,
Until her soul sweat, is a pigeon's torment,
And she is sent a babe to the other world,
Columbo's death will not be satisfied,
And I but wound her with a two edged feather;
I must do more, I have all opportunity,
(She by the King now made my charge) but she's
So much a turtle I shall lose by killing her,
Perhaps do her a pleasure, and preferment;
That must not be.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Is not this she, that would be thought to have been
Columbo's mistress? Madam, his grace is private,
And would not be disturbed, you may displease him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What will your worship wager that he shall
Be pleased again before we part.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll say this diamond madam, 'gainst a kiss,
And trust yourself to keep the stakes.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have long had an appetite to this lady,
But the lords keep her up so high — this toy
May bring her on.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: This interruption tastes not of good manners.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But where necessity my lord compels,
The boldness may meet pardon, and when you
Have found my purpose, I may less appear
Unmannerly.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: To th' business.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It did please
Your nephew, sir, before his death to credit me
With so much honourable favour, I
Am come to tender to his nearest of blood,
Yourself, what does remain a debt to him.
Not to delay your grace with circumstance,
That deed, if you accept, makes you my heir
Of no contemptible estate — this way
Is only left to tie up scurrile tongues,
And saucy men, that since Columbo's death
Venture to libel on my pride, and folly;
His greatness, and this gift which I enjoy,
Still for my life, beyond which term; a kingdom's,
Nothing, will curb the giddy spleens of men
That live on impudent rhyme, and railing at
Each wandering fame they catch.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Madam, this bounty
Will bind my gratitude and care to serve you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I am your grace's servant.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Antonelli,
And when this noble lady visits me
Let her not wait.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What think you my officious, sir; his grace
Is pleased, you may conjecture? I may keep
Your gem, the kiss was never yours.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sweet madam —

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Talk if you dare, you know I must not wait,
And so farewell for this time.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: 'Tis in my brain already, and it forms
Apace, good, excellent revenge, and pleasant!
She's now within my talons, 'tis too cheap
A satisfaction for Columbo's death,
Only to kill her by soft charm or force,
I'll rifle first her darling chastity,
'Twil be after time enough to poison her,
And she to th' world be thought her own destroyer.
As I will frame the circumstance, this night
All may be finished; for the colonel,
Her agent in my nephew's death (Whom I
Disturbed at counsel with her) I may reach him
Hereafter, and be master of his fate.
We starve our conscience when we thrive in state.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Placentia, we two are only left
Of my lady's servants, let us be true
To her, and one another, and be sure
When we are at prayers, to curse the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I pity my sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: I pity her too, but am a little angry;
She might have found another time to lose
Her wits.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: That I were a man?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: What wouldst thou do Placentia?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I would revenge my lady.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: 'Tis better being a woman, thou mayst do
Things that may prosper better, and the fruit
Be thy own another day.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Your wit still loves
To play the wanton.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: 'Tis a sad time Placentia,
Some pleasure would do well, the truth is, I
Am weary of my life, and I would have
One fit of mirth before I leave the world.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Do not you blush to talk thus wildly?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: 'Tis good manners
To be a little mad after my lady;
But I ha' done; who is with her now?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Madam Valeria.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Not Celinda? There's a lady for my humour,
A pretty book of flesh and blood, and well
Bound up, in a fair letter too; would I
Had her with all the errata.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: She has not
An honourable fame.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Her fame? that's nothing,
A little stain, her wealth will fetch again
The colour, and bring honour into her cheeks
As fresh; if she were mine, and I had her
Exchequer. I know the way to make her honest,
Honest to th' touch, the test, and the last trial.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: How prithee?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Why, first I would marry her, that's a verb material;
Then I would print her with an index.
Expurgatorius, a table drawn
Of her court heresies, and when she's read
Cum privilegio, who dares call her whore?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I'll leave you, if you talk thus.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: I ha' done,

sp.speaker: Placentia,
sp.l: Thou mayest be better company
After another progress; and now tell me,
Didst ever hear of such a patient madness
As my lady is possessed with? she has raved
But twice; and she would fright the Cardinal,
Or at a supper if she did but poison him,
It were a frenzy I could bear withal;
She calls him her dear governor —

div.stage: Enter Hernando disguised having a letter.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Who is this?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Her secretary? Sir,
Here is a letter if it may have so
Much happiness to kiss her grace's hand.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: From whom?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: That's not in your commission sir
To ask, or mine to satisfy, she will want
No understanding when she reads.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Alas,
Under your favour sir, you are mistaken,
Her grace did never more want understanding.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Have you not heard, her scull is broken sir
And many pieces taken out, she's mad.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The sad fame of her distraction
Has two much truth it seems.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: If please you sir
To expect a while, I will present the letter.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Pray do
How long has she been thus distempered sir?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Before the Cardinal came to govern here,
Who for that reason by the King was made
Her guardian, we are now at his devotion.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: A lamb given up to a tiger! may diseases
Soon eat him through his heart!

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Your pardon sir,
I love that voice, I know it too, a little,
Are not you? be not angry noble sir,
I can with ease be ignorant again,
And think you are another man, but if
You be that valiant gentleman they call —

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Whom? What?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: That killed, I would not name him if I thought
You were not pleased to be that very gentleman.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Am I betrayed?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: The devil sha'not
Betray you here, kill me, and I will take
My death you are the noble colonel;
We are all bound to you for the general's death,
Valiant Hernando? when my lady knows
You are here, I hope 'twil fetch her wits again,
But do not talk too loud, we are not all
Honest i'th' house, some are the Cardinal's creatures.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Thou wert faithful to thy lady, I am glad
'Tis night, but tell me how the churchman uses
The Duchess?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: He carries angels in his tongue, and face, but I
Suspect his heart, this is one of his spawns.
Signior Antonelli.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Honest Antonio.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: And how, and how — a friend of mine, where is
The Cardinal's grace?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: That will be never answered.

sp.speaker: Aut.
sp.l: He means to sup here with the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Will he?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We'll have the charming bottles at my chamber,
Bring that gentleman, we'll be mighty merry.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I may disturb your jollity.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Farewell sweet —

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Dear Antonelli — a round pox confound you.
This is court rhetoric at the back stairs.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Do you know this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: My lady presently dismissed Valeria,
And bade me bring him to her bedchamber.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: The gentleman has an honest face.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Her words fell from her with some evenness and joy.
Her grace desires your presence.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I'll attend her.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: I would this soldier had the Cardinal
Upon a promontory, with what a spring
The churchman would leap down, it were a spectacle
Most rare to see him topple from the precipice,
And souse in the salt water with a noise
To stun the fishes; and if he fell into
A net, what wonder would the simple seagulls
Have, to draw up the o'rgrown lobster,
So ready boiled? he shall have my good wishes,
This colonels coming may be lucky. I
Will be sure none shall interrupt 'em.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Is her grace at opportunity?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: No sweet madam,
She is asleep , her gentlewoman says.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My business is but visit, I'll expect.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: That must not be, although I like your company.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You are grown rich Mr. secretary.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: I madam, alas!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I hear you are upon another purchase.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: I upon a purchase?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If you want any sum —

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: If I could purchase your sweet favour madam?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You shall command me, and my fortune sir.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have observed you sir a stayed,
And prudent gentleman — and I shall want —

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Not me?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: A father for some infant; he has credit
Ith' world; I am not the first cast lady
Has married a secretary.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Shall I wait upon you?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: Any whither.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I may chance lead you then —

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: I shall be honoured to obey, my blood
Is up, and in this humour I'm for any thing.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Well sir, I'll try your manhood.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: 'Tis my happiness,
You cannot please me better.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: This was struck
I'th' opportunity.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.l: I am made for ever.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Dear madam, do not weep.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You're very welcome,
I ha' done, I won't shed a tear more
Till I meet Alvarez, then I'll weep for joy;
He was a fine young gentleman, and sung sweetly,
And you had heard him but the night before
We were married, you would ha' sworn he had been
A swan, and sung his own sad epitaph;
But we'll talk o'the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Would his death
Might ransom your fair sense, he should not live
To triumph in the loss, beshrew my manhood;
But I begin to melt.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I pray sir tell me,
For I can understand, although they say
I have lost my wits; but they are safe enough,
And I shall have 'em when the Cardinal dies;
Who had a letter from his nephew too
Since he was slain.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: From whence?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I know not where he is? but in some bower
Within a garden he is making chaplets,
And means to send me one, but I'll not take it,
I have flowers enough I thank him while I live.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: But do you love your governor?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Yes, but I'll never marry him, I am promised
Already.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: To whom madam?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Do not you
Blush when you ask me that, must not you be
My husband? I know why, but that's a secret;
Indeed if you believe me, I do love
No man alive so well as you, the Cardinal
Shall never know't, he'll kill us both, and yet
He says he loves me dear, and has promised
To make me well again, but I'm afraid,
One time or other he will give me poison.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Prevent him madam, and take nothing from him.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Why, do you think 'twil hurt me?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: It will kill you.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I shall but die, and meet my dear loved lord,
Whom when I have kissed, I'll come again, and work
A bracelet of my hair for you to carry him,
When you are going to heaven, the poesy shall
Be my own name, in little tears, that I
Will weep next winter, which congealed i'th' frost
Will show like seed-pearl, you'll deliver it?
I know he'll love, and wear it for my sake.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: She is quite lost.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I pray give me sir, your pardon,
I know I talk not wisely, but if you had
The burden of my sorrow, you would miss
Sometimes your better reason; now I'm well,
What will you do when the Cardinal comes?
He must not see you for the world.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: He sha'not,
I'll take my leave before he come.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Nay stay,
I shall have no friend left me when you go,
He will but sup, he sha'not stay to lie with me,
I have the picture of my lord a-bed,
Three are to much this weather.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Madam, the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: He shall sup with the devil.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I dare not stay,
The shank will be angry, I'll come again.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: This sorrow is no fable, now I find
My curiosity is sadly satisfied;
Ha? if the Duchess in her straggled wits,
Let fall words to betray me to the Cardinal,
The panther will not leap more fierce to meet
His prey, when a long want of food hath parched
His starved maw, than he to print his rage
And tear my heartstrings, every thing is fatal,
And yet she talked sometimes with chain of sense,
And said she loved me; ha, they come not yet;
I have a sword about me, and I left
My own security to visit death.
Yet I may pause a little, and consider
Which way does lead me to't most honourably;
Does not the chamber that I walk in tremble?
What will become of her, and me, and all
The world in one small hour? I do not think
Ever to see the day again, the wings
Of night spread o'er me like a sable hearse-cloth,
The stars are all close mourners too; but I
Must not alone to the cold silent grave,
I must not; if thou canst Alvarez open
That ebon curtain, and behold the man,
When the world's justice fails shall right thy ashes,
And feed their thirst with blood, thy Duchess is
Almost a ghost already; and doth wear
Her body like a useless upper garment,
The trim and fashion of it lost. Ha?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: You need not doubt me, sir, my lady prays
You would not think it long, she in my ear,
Commanded me to tell you, that when last
She drank, she had happy wishes to your health.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: And did the Cardinal pledge it?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: He was not
Invited to't, nor must he know you are here.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: What do they talk of prithee?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: His grace is very pleasant
And kind to her, but her returns are after
The sad condition of her sense, sometimes unjointed.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: They have music.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: A lute only,
His grace prepared, they say, the best of Italy
That waits upon my lord.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: He thinks the Duchess
Is stung with a tarantula.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Your pardon.
My duty is expected.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Gentle lady. — a voice too?

lg.head: Song within.
lg.l: S. come my Daphne, come away,
We do waste the crystal day;
'Tis Strephon calls. Da what says my love?
S. come follow to the myrtle grove,
Where Venus shall prepare
New chaplets for thy hair.
D. were I shut up within a tree,
I'd rend my bark to follow thee.
S. My shepherdess, make haste,
The minutes slide too fast:
D. in those cooler shades will I
Blind, as Cupid, kiss thine eye.
S. in thy bosom then I'll stay,
In such warm snow who would not lose his way.
We'll laugh and leave the world behind,
And gods themselves that see,
Shall envy thee, and me;
But never find
Such joys, when they embrace a deity.

sp.l: If at this distance I distinguish, 'tis not
Church music, and the air's wanton, and no anthem
Sung to't, but some strange ode of love, and kisses,
What should this mean? — ha, he is coming hither,
I am betrayed, he marches in her hand,
I'll trust a little more, mute as the arras
My sword and I here.

div.stage: Enter Cardinal, Duchess, Antonelli, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Wait you in the first chamber, and let none
Presume to interrupt us.
She is pleasant; now for some art to poison all her innocence.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I do not like the Cardinal's humour, he
Little suspects what guest is in my chamber.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Now madam you are safe.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: How means your lordship?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Safe in my arms, sweet Duchess.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Do not hurt me.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Not for the treasures of the world, you are
My pretty charge, had I as many lives
As I have careful thoughts, to do you service,
I should think all a happy forfeit to
Delight your grace one minute; 'tis a heaven
To see you smile.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What kindness call you this?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: It cannot want a name while you preserve
So plentiful a sweetness, it is love.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Of me? how shall I know't my lord?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: By this, and this, swift messengers to whisper
Our hearts to one another.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Pray do you come a-wooing ?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Yes sweet madam,
You cannot be so cruel to deny me.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What my lord?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Another kiss.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Can you
Dispense with this my lord? Alas I fear
Hernando is asleep, or vanished from me.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I have mocked my blood into a flame, and what
My angry soul had formed for my revenge,
Is now the object of my amorous sense,
I have taken a strong enchantment from her lips,
And fear I shall forgive Columbo's death
If she consent to my embrace; come madam.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Whither my lord?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: But to your bed or couch,
Where if you will be kind, and but allow
Yourself a knowledge, love whose shape and raptures
Wise poets have but glorified in dreams,
Shall make your chamber his eternal palace;
And with such active and essential streams
Of new delights glide o'er your bosom, you
Shall wonder to what unknown world you are
By some blessed change translated; why d'ye pause?
And look so wild? will you deny your governor?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: How came you by that cloven foot?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Your fancy
Would turn a traitor to your happiness;
I am your friend, you must be kind.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Unhand me,
Or I'll cry out a rape.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: You won't sure?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I have been cozened with Hernando's shadow,
Here's none but heaven to hear me, help, a rape,

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Are you so good at understanding then,
I must use other argument.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Go to, Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Hernando, murder, treason, help.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: An army sha'not rescue thee, your blood
Is much inflamed, I have brought a lancet wi'me,
Shall open your hot veins, and cool your fever;
To vex thy parting soul, it was the same
Engine that pinced Columbo's heart.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Help, murder.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: Some ring the bell, 'twil raise the court,
My lord is murdered, 'tis Hernando.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I'll make you all some sport, — so, now we are even,
Where is the Duchess, I would take my leave
Of her, and then bequeath my curse among you.

div.stage: Enter King, Duchess, Valeria, lords, guard.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How come these bloody objects?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: With a trick my sword found out, I hope he's paid.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo
sp.l: I hope so to; a surgeon for my lord Cardinal.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hernando?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Justice, o justice sir, against a ravisher.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Sir I ha' done you service.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: A bloody service.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: 'Tis pure scarlet.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: After such care to perfect my revenge
Thus banded out o'th' world by a woman's plot?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I have preserved the Duchess from a rape,
Goodnight to me and all the world for ever.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: So impious.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: 'Tis most true, Alvarez blood
Is now revenged, I find my brain return,
And every straggling sense repairing home.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I have deserved you should turn from me sir,
My life hath been prodigiously wicked,
My blood is now the kingdom's balm; o sir,
I have abused your ear, your trust, your people,
And my own sacred office, my conscience
Feels now the sting, o show your charity,
And with your pardon like a cool soft gale
Fan my poor sweating soul; that wanders through
Unhabitable climes, and parched deserts;
But I am lost, if the great world forgive me,
Unless I find your mercy for a crime
You know not madam, yet against your life.
I must confess, more than my black intents
Upon your honour, you're already poisoned.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: By whom?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: By me,
In the revenge I owed Columbo's loss,
With your last meat was mixed a poison that
By subtle, and by sure degrees must let in death.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Look to the Duchess, our physicians?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Stay, I will deserve her mercy, though I cannot
Call back the deed, in proof of my repentance,
If the last breath of a now dying man
May gain your charity, and belief, receive
This ivory box, in it an antidote
Above that they boast the great magistral medicine,
That powder mixed with wine by a most rare
And quick access to the heart will fortify it
Against the rage of the most nimble poison,
I am not worthy to present her with it,
O take it and preserve her innocent life.

sp.speaker: 1 lo.
sp.l: Strange, he should have a good thing in such readiness.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: This that which in my jealousy and state
Trusting to false predictions of my birth,
That I should die by poison, I preserved
For my own safety, wonder not, I made,
That my companion was to be my refuge.

div.stage: Enter servant with a bowl of wine.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.l: Here's some touch of grace.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: In greater proof of my pure thoughts I take
This first, and with my dying breath confirm
My penitence, it may benefit her life,
But not my wounds; o hasten to preserve her,
And though I merit not her pardon, let not
Her fair soul be divorced

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: This is some charity, may it prosper madam.

sp.speaker: Valeria.
sp.l: How does your grace?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: And must I owe my life to him whose death
Was my ambition? take this free acknowledgement,
I had intent this night with my own hand
To be Alvarez justicer.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You were mad,
And thought passed apprehension of revenge.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: That shape I did usurp, great sir, to give
My art more freedom and defence, but when
Hernando came to visit me, I thought
I might defer my execution,
Which his own rage supplied without my guilt,
And when his lust grew high, met with his blood.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.l: The Cardinal smiles.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Now my revenge has met
With you my nimble Duchess, I have taken
A shape to give my act more freedom too,
And now I am sure she's poisoned, with that dose
I gave her last.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thou'rt not so horrid?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Ha! some cordial.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Alas no preservative
Hath wings to overtake it, were her heart
Locked in a quarry, it would search, and kill
Before the aids can reach it; I am sure
You sha' not now laugh at me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How came you by that poison?

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I prepared it,
Resolving when I had enjoyed her, which
The colonel prevented, by some art
To make her take it, and by death conclude
My last revenge; you have the fatal story.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: This is so great a wickedness, it will
Exceed belief.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: I knew I could not live.

sp.speaker: Surgeon.
sp.l: Your wounds, sir, were not desperate.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Not mortal? ha? were they not mortal?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: If I have skill in surgery.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Then I have caught myself in my own engine.

sp.speaker: 2 lo.
sp.l: It was your fate you said to die by poison.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: That was my own prediction to abuse
Your faith, no humane art can now resist it,
I feel it knocking at the seat of life,
It must come in, I have wracked all my own
To try your charities, new it would be rare,
If you but waft me with a little prayer,
My wings that flag may catch the wind, but 'tis
In vain, the mist is risen, and there's none
To steer my wand'ring bark.

sp.speaker: 1 Lo.
sp.l: He's dead?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: With him
Die all deceived trust.

sp.speaker: 2 lo.
sp.l: This was a strange impiety.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: When men
Of gifts and sacred function once decline
From virtue, their ill deeds transcend example.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: The minute's come that I must take my leave too.
Your hand great sir, and though you be a King,
We may exchange forgiveness, heaven forgive,
And all the world. I come, I come Alvarez

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Dispose their bodies for becoming funeral;
How much are Kings abused by those they take
To royal grace? whom when they cherish most
By nice indulgence, they do often arm
Against themselves; from whence this maxim springs,
None have more need of perspectives than Kings.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.p: Mr. Pollaed, where's Mr. Pollard for the epilogue?
div.stage: He is thrust upon the stage, and falls.

sp.speaker: Epilogue.
sp.l: I am coming to you gentlemen, the poet
Has helped me thus far on my way, but I'll
Be even with him; the play is a tragedy,
The first that ever he composed for us,
Wherein he thinks he has done prettily,
And I am sensible; I prithee look
Is nothing out of joint? has he broke nothing?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Nor sir, I hope.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.l: Yes, he has broke his epilogue all to pieces,
Canst thou put it together again?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: Epi.
sp.l: Nor I, prithee be gone, hum? Mr. poet,
I have a teeming mind to be revenged.
You may assist, and not be seen in't now.
If you please gentlemen, for I do know
He listens to the issue of his cause,
But blister not your hands in his applause,
Your private smile, your nod, or hum, to tell
My fellows, that you like the business well;
And when without a clap you go away,
I'll drink a small-beer health to his second day;
And break his heart, or make him swear, and rage,
He'll write no more for the unhappy stage;
But that's too much, so we should lose; faith show it,
And if you like his play, 'tis as well, he knew it.

div.head: A catalogue of the author's poems already printed

list.head: Comedies and tragi-comedies.
list.item: falsely ascribed to Jo. Fletcher. the coronation
The changes, or love in a maze
The ball, or French dancing master

div.p: A masque of the four honourable inns of court, presented before the King and Queen's majesty at Whitehall in the banqueting house.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
